program main
  implicit none
  integer :: n, a, b, i, found
  integer, dimension(:), allocatable :: list1, list2

  read(*,*) n, a, b

  allocate(list1(a))
  read(*,*) (list1(i), i=1,a)

  allocate(list2(b)) read(*,*) (list2(i), i=1,b)

  found = 0
  do i = 1, a
     if (list1(i) == 1) then
        found = 1
        exit
     end if
  end do

  !

We can do:

integer :: count, x
count = 0
x = ... (1 or 2)
do while (x > 0) if (mod(x,2) == 1) count = count +1
   x = x /2
end do But since x is either 1 or 2, this loop will run once for 1 (count 1), and for 2 (mod(2,2)=0, then x becomes 1, then mod(1,2)=1 → count 1, then x becomes 0. So total count is 1. So the code can be written as:

x = 1 if found else 2

count = 0

do while (x >0)
   if (mod(x,2) ==1) count = count +1
   x = x/2

write(*,*) count But since it's always 1, but to follow the code's logic, perhaps it's better to compute it properly. So modifying the program:

program main
  implicit none
  integer :: n, a, b, i, found, x, count
  integer, dimension(:), allocatable :: list1, list2

  read(*,*) n, a, b

  allocate(list1(a))
  read(*,*) (list1(i), i=1,a)

  allocate(list2(b))
  read(*,*) (list2(i), i=1,b)

  found = 0 do i = 1, a
     if (list1(i) == 1) then
        found = 1
        exit
     end if
  end do

  if (found ==1) then
     x =1
  else
     x=2
  end if

  count =0
  do while (x >0)
     if (mod(x,2) ==1) then
        count = count +1
     end if
     x = x/2
  end do

  write(*,*) count

end program main

This program will compute the count properly, even though it's always 1.

  implicit none
  integer :: n, a, b, i, found
  integer, dimension(:), allocatable :: list1, list2

  read(*,*) n, a, b

  allocate(list1(a))
  read(*,*) (list1(i), i=1,a)

  allocate(list2(b))
  read(*,*) (list2(i), i=1,b)

  found = 0

     if (list1(i) == 1) then
        found = 1
        exit
     end if
  end do

  ! The first element is 1 if found, else 2
  ! The count of 1's in binary of either is 1

end program main

program main
  implicit none

  integer, dimension(:), allocatable :: list1, list2

  read(*,*) (list2(i), i=1,b)

  found = 0
  do i = 1, a
     if (list1(i) == 1) then
        found = 1
        exit
     end if
  end do

  if (found ==1) then
     x =1
  else
     x=2
  end if

  count =0
  do while (x >0)
     if (mod(x,2) ==1) then
        count = count +1
     end if
     x = x/2
  end do

  write(*,*) count

end program main

This program will compute the count properly, even though it's always 1. This is better because it follows the logic of the original code, even if the result is the same.

Therefore, this is the correct Fortran program.
